user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarUnlock_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarUnlock_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    status = pthread_mutex_unlock(&impl->mut);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarUnlock_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments modify the function parameter token (the pointer itself). Details:
- The function signature is int32 OS_CondVarUnlock_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token); token is a pointer parameter and there are no assignments to token (no statements like token = ..., ++token, or similar).
- The macro call impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token); expands so that the index is computed via OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&( *token )), which is equivalent to passing token to OS_ObjectIndexFromToken. Taking the address of the dereferenced token does not modify the pointer parameter; it merely produces a pointer value for the inline function to read token->obj_idx.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token) only reads token->obj_idx (no writes), so the object referred to by the pointer is not modified by that function.
- The rest of the function uses impl and calls pthread_mutex_unlock(&impl->mut); which does not modify the token parameter.

Therefore there are no fragments that appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the provided code.
